questions.text: Which of the following is the ultimate long-term desired state towards which all the resources are directed?
questions.solution:
The goal is the ultimate desired state towards which objectives and resources are directed. It is long-term and not constrained by time or resources.

The plan is the blueprint for taking action in order to achieve the goal.

Option A: Target refers to the quantifiable and achievable mid-term endpoints in the plan.

Option B: Mission describes the cause of the existence of the programme.

Option D: The objectives are short-term endpoints. They are precise points in the plan. They are either achieved or unachieved.

questions.text: Which of the following is a set of rules that helps ensure maximum use of the resources and efforts?
questions.solution:
Procedure is a set of rules for carrying out work. It helps to ensure the maximum use of resources and efforts.

Option B: Programme is a sequence of activities designed to implement policies and accomplish objectives.

Option C: Schedule is a time sequence for the work to be done.

Option D: Target refers to the quantifiable and achievable mid-term endpoints in the plan.

questions.text:
A team of doctors is planning to conduct a survey on the prevalence of infective diarrhea in a village. What is the correct sequence of steps involved in the planning of this activity?
  1. Establishment of objectives and goals
  2. Fixing priorities
  3. Analysis of the health situation
  4. Assessment of resources
questions.solution:
The planning cycle includes the following steps:

  1. Analysis of the health situation
  2. Establishment of objectives and goals
  3. Assessment of resources
  4. Fixing priorities
  5. Writing-up of a formulated plan
  6. Programming and implementation
  7. Monitoring
  8. Evaluation

The planning cycle has been summarized in the following image:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the evaluation of health programs?
questions.solution:
Repeatability is not a component of the evaluation of health programs.

Components of evaluation are:

(Mnemonic: Ryan Always Ate An Egg Every Evening)

  • Relevance
  • Adequacy
  • Accessibility
  • Acceptability
  • Effectiveness
  • Efficiency
  • Effect or impact

The steps of evaluation of a health programme are:

  1. Determine what is to be evaluated: structure, process, or outcome
  2. Establish standards and criteria
  3. Plan the methodology to be applied
  4. Gather information
  5. Analyze the results
  6. Take action
  7. Re-evaluate

questions.text: Which of the following techniques is based on behavioral sciences?
questions.solution:
Management by objective is based on behavioral sciences.

Management methods used in health programmes are either quantitative or based on behavioral sciences.

Methods based on behavioral sciences include: 

  • Organizational design
  • Personnel management
  • Communication
  • Information systems
  • Management by objectives (MBO)

Quantitative methods include:

  • Cost-benefit analysis
  • Cost-effective analysis
  • Cost–accounting
  • Input-output analysis
  • Model
  • Systems analysis
  • Network analysis - includes programme evaluation and review technique (PERT) and critical path method (CPM)
  • Planning–programming–budgeting system (PPBS)
  • Work sampling
  • Decision making

questions.text: Which of the following is a quantitative method of management?
questions.solution:
Cost-benefit analysis is a quantitative method of management.

In this method, the economic benefits of any programme are compared with the costs incurred. The benefit of the programme is expressed in monetary units. The main drawback here is that the benefits of a health programme cannot always be expressed in monetary terms.

Management methods used in health programmes are either quantitative or based on behavioral sciences.

Methods based on behavioral sciences include: 

  • Organizational design
  • Personnel management
  • Communication
  • Information systems
  • Management by objectives (MBO)

Quantitative methods include:

  • Cost-benefit analysis
  • Cost-effective analysis
  • Cost–accounting
  • Input-output analysis
  • Model
  • Systems analysis
  • Network analysis - includes programme evaluation and review technique (PERT) and critical path method (CPM)
  • Planning–programming–budgeting system (PPBS)
  • Work sampling
  • Decision making

questions.text: In which of the following methods of management is the benefit measured in natural units?
questions.solution:
In cost-effective analysis (CEA), benefits are measured in natural units of the outcomes of the programs.

  Cost-effective analysis Cost-benefit analysis
Cost measured in Health units Monetary units
Outcome measured in

Natural (health) units like life-years gained, cases prevented, etc.

Most comprehensive indicator - quality-adjusted life years (QALYs)

 Monetary gain 
Uses

Evaluation of activities under a programme and comparing clinical strategies to deliver the same

 At executive level of government (eg, budgeting, etc.)

questions.text: What is the programme evaluation and review technique used for?
questions.solution:
The programme evaluation and review technique (PERT) is used for network analysis.

It is a type of quantitative management technique which helps in detailed planning and comprehensive supervision. 

Related Pearl: Network Analysis in Health Management

A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Two types of network analysis: PERT and CPM

1. Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)

  • An arrow diagram of all events in logical sequence is drawn.
  • Time to finish each activity can be calculated and critical activities can be identified.
  • It aids in planning, scheduling and monitoring of the project.

2. Critical Path Method (CPM)

  • The longest path of the network is called the critical path.
  • A delay in the critical path will cause a delay in the entire project.

questions.text: Which of the following depicts the critical path in the project plan shown below?
questions.solution:
The critical path in the critical path method (CPM) is the longest path denoted by path 4 (7 days) in the plan shown above.

Any delay in the critical path will cause a delay in the entire project.

Related Pearl: Network Analysis in Health Management

A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Two types of network analysis: PERT and CPM

1. Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)

  • An arrow diagram of all events in logical sequence is drawn.
  • Time to finish each activity can be calculated and critical activities can be identified.
  • It aids in planning, scheduling and monitoring of the project.

2. Critical Path Method (CPM)

  • The longest path of the network is called the critical path.
  • A delay in the critical path will cause a delay in the entire project.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the zero-based budgeting approach?

choices.text: It does not rely on data from previous budget
It is a management method based on behavioral sciences
It proceeds from resource to target
It is not a priority-based budgeting

questions.solution:
In the zero-based budgeting approach (ZBB), the budget for each new period is created starting from a zero base. It does not rely on the data from the previous budget. 

It is a quantitative method of management.

Traditional Budgeting Zero-based Budgeting
Previous year's budget used as a template Start from zero base with newly set targets, followed by priority-based allocation of resources (target to resource)
Only new expenses need to be justified Each expense needs to be justified, both old and recurring expenses
Used to study changes in expenditure Used to study the cost-benefit analysis
Activities are directed towards monitoring of expenditure Activities are directed towards achievements of objectives

questions.text: A hospital administrator is systematically recording the activities of his team at regular intervals. What is this known as?
questions.solution:
Work sampling is a systematic observation and recording of activities of one or more individuals carried out at regular or random intervals.

It is a type of quantitative method of management. It helps in standardizing the methods of performing the jobs and determining the need for manpower.

Management methods used in health programmes are either quantitative or based on behavioral sciences.

Methods based on behavioral sciences include: 

  • Organizational design
  • Personnel management
  • Communication
  • Information systems
  • Management by objectives (MBO)

Quantitative methods include:

  • Cost-benefit analysis
  • Cost-effective analysis
  • Cost–accounting
  • Input-output analysis
  • Model
  • Systems analysis
  • Network analysis - includes programme evaluation and review technique (PERT) and critical path method (CPM)
  • Planning–programming–budgeting system (PPBS)
  • Work sampling
  • Decision making

questions.text: Which committee had recommended a bachelor degree in medical education for rural health services?

choices.text: High-level expert group on universal health coverage
Committee on Integration of Health Services

questions.solution:
The high-level expert group (HLEG) on universal health coverage under the aegis of the Planning Commission of India suggested a 3.5 year bachelor degree course in medical education for rural health services.

This was planned for the 12th five-year plan (2012-2017). The degree given was B.Sc Community Health, and these rural health care practitioners were to be called community health officers.

International Universal Health Coverage Day is observed annually on December 12. The campaign aims to raise awareness of the need for strong and resilient health systems and universal health coverage.

questions.text: Who was appointed as the chairman of the Health Survey and Development Committee in 1943?
questions.solution:
Sir Joseph William Bhore was appointed as the chairman of the Health Survey and Development Committee in 1943. This committee was hence named the Bhore committee.

questions.text: Which health planning committee proposed the 3 million plan?
questions.solution:
The 3 million plan was proposed by the Bhore Committee.

It proposed to set up the following in the long-term:

  • Primary health units with 75-bedded hospitals for each 10,000 to 20,000 population
  • Secondary units with 650 beds
  • District hospitals with 2,500 beds

 As a short-term measure, it was proposed that each PHC must cater to 40,000 people and have:

  • 2 medical officers, 4 public health nurses, 1 nurse
  • 4 midwives, 4 dais, 2 sanitary inspectors, 2 health assistants
  • 1 pharmacist
  • 15 other class IV employees

questions.text: What is the provision of preventive, curative, and promotional health services to every individual called?
questions.solution: Comprehensive health care as stated by the Bhore committee means giving integrated preventive, curative, and promotional health care to every individual, irrespective of their ability to pay.

questions.text: In the inventory management of drug stores, which of the following is a component of the VED method?
questions.solution:
The 'D' in the VED method stands for desirable.

VED is a method of inventory management used mainly in drug stores and pharmacies. 

The drugs are classified in three categories as follows:

  • V - Vital drugs. Items whose absence cannot be tolerated (10% of total items).
  • E - Essential drugs. Items whose absence can be tolerated for some time (40% of total items).
  • D - Desirable drugs. Items whose absence can be tolerated for a long time (50% of total items).

questions.text:
A drug store owner uses the following technique of inventory management to procure drugs. What is this method known as?
Drugs Cost used (%)    Items (%)
Outstandingly important          70   15
Average importance      25 30
Relatively unimportant    5 55
questions.solution:
The method of analysis depicted above is the ABC analysis (always better control). It refers to a type of inventory management in which items are divided into 3 categories according to their cost.

This type of analysis aims to calculate expenditures of large proportions on a small number of items and vice versa. It makes it easier to understand how to control the majority of expenditure by analyzing the small numbers of items it is being spent on. 

The table below explains ABC analysis:

Category Label Cost (%) Items (%)
Class A - items Outstandingly important 70 15
Class B - items Average importance  25 30
Class C - items Relatively unimportant 5 55

Other types of inventory management are:

  • FSN - Fast-slow-non moving drugs.
  • VED - Vital-essential-desirable drugs
  • HML - High-cost medium-cost low-cost drugs. In HML analysis the items are categories into H, M, L category based on unit cost.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the National Health Policy of 2017?

choices.text: Increase public health expenditure to 5% of GDP by 2025
Access to safe water and sanitation to all by 2020
Achieve elimination of lymphatic filariasis by 2017

questions.solution:
National Health Policy (NHP) 2017 aims to increase the public health expenditure from existing 1.15% to 2.5% of the GDP by 2025.

The draft of the policy from 2015 was passed by the government in 2017 and is called the National Health Policy (NHP) 2017. 

Components of NHP 2017 Quantitative goals and objectives
Health status and programme impact
  • ↑ life expectancy at birth from 67.5 to 70 by 2025
  • ↓ infant mortality rate to 28 by 2019
  • ↓ neonatal mortality to 16 and stillbirth rate to a single digit by 2025
  • ↓ maternal mortality ratio from current levels to 100 by 2020
  • Elimination of lymphatic filariasis by 2017
 
Health systems performance  
  • ↑ utilization of public health facilities by 50% by 2025
  • ↑ Antenatal care coverage above 90%
  • > 90% of newborns to be fully immunized by 1 year of age by 2025
  • Access to safe water and sanitation to all by 2020 (Swachh Bharat Mission)
Health systems financing  
  • ↑ public health expenditure to 2.5% of GDP by 2025
  • ↑ state sector health spending to > 8% of budget by 2020
Priority actions to improve the environment for health  
  • Swachh Bharat Abhiyan
  • Balanced healthy diets and regular exercise
  • Addressing tobacco, alcohol, and substance abuse
  • Yatri Suraksha to reduce death due to accidents
  • Nirbhaya Nari for action against gender violence
  • Reduced stress and improved safety in workplaces
  • Reducing indoor and outdoor air pollution
Other provisions
  • NEET exam for UG
  • ↑ provisions for treatment and diagnosis in HIV-centered communities 
  • Establishment of nursing schools in every district
  • Food safety

questions.text: Which article of the Indian Constitution confers Right to Life to the citizens of India?
questions.solution:
The Right to Life is given in Article 21 of the Indian Constitution.

Option A: Article 11 defines the right of the parliament to regulate the right of citizenship by law.

Option C: Article 23 defines the prohibition of traffic in human beings and forced labor.

Option D: Article 25 defines the freedom of conscience and free profession, practice, and propagation of religion.

questions.text: Which of the following is part of the concurrent list of the Indian Constitution?

choices.text: Fishing and fisheries beyond territorial waters

questions.solution:
Adulteration of food is included under the concurrent list.

The legislative section of the seventh schedule is divided into three lists:

  • Union list - a list of 100 items on which the parliament has exclusive power to legislate
  • State list - a list of 61 items on which the state government has exclusive power to legislate
  • Concurrent list - a list of 52 items on which both central and state governments have the power to legislate
